title: Before 1 July 2019, will Daniel Ortega cease to be president of Nicaragua?

The publication also reiterates that the only vulnerable point of the regime is the possibility of greater United States sanctions.

Nicaragua is situated in a close proximity with Venezuela and the Venezuelian president is still in power, despite that the most of the public and international attention is focused on Maduro, not Ortega. Giving the example of Venezuela is helpful because Venezuela is from the same region with similar problems to Nicaragua- state run corruption, low economy,issues with law enforcement and daily disrespect of human rights, etc. Despite having different reasons which made both presidents to be seen by (part of) their citizens as illegitimate rulers, it is giving a significant analytical contrast  for measuring how possible it is realistically currently Daniel Ortega to cease to be a president of Nicaragua before/after or in similar time with Venezualian President Nicolas Maduro. Moreover, as per today (17th May) Nicaragua seems to be a left out blind spot for the attention of politicians and all international attention of powers such as the US, UK, China, and even EU is consumed by other issues (Brexit, Venezuela, European elections, China, Boeing vs Airbus, etc, etc,) leaving Nicaragua to manage on itself without external pressures. The external pressures are important in measuring to what extent it is possible Ortega to leave his office at any point, not just in July. But with the interest being low in terms of Nicaragua and practically no external pressure except from NGOs, Ortega is in a more or less safe position to not be removed from power before July 2019. Some questions I think someone more proficient in Latin American politics can answer are:
1. Why is Nicaragua less important than Venezuela?
2. Is there any regional framework for cooperation that might influence such decisions and if not- why?

Thousands of Nicaraguans have protested President Daniel Ortega's Sandinista government after he implemented a pension reform which raised taxes and cut benefits. This reform was put in place as a result of the Sandinista's decade long misuse of funds which left the government insolvent. In addition, President Ortega has take steps over the years to slowly dismantle the country's democracy by stealing elections, reforming the constitution to his benefit, and bribing major media outlets. His actions have left citizens protesting for his removal, and the international community has done the same with the US placing sanctions on the country. Although there have been mass protests by citizens and condemnation by other countries, is is very unlikely that Ortega will cease to be president as he has remained in power unchallenged with the support of the Nicaraguan police and a gang known as the Sandinista Youth. Ortega has rejected a referendum on holding early elections believing that the opposition would not accept any unfavorable result. In late July the Ortega government faced pressure from international groups and sanctions from the United States. in mid-March Ortega announced the release of all people arrested during anti-Ortega protests.The violence between protestors and government forces has resulted in the death of 300 people and over 600 arrests.  Ortega has retained power during the year-long protest, while making few concessions. While pass performance is no guarantee of future results, Ortega's ability to hold on to power through deadly protests signifies how far he is willing to go to retain power. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-nicaragua-protests-usa/nicaraguas-ortega-rejects-early-elections-u-s-rebukes-crackdown-idUSKBN1KK1OW

Over the past couple of elections in Nicaragua, it has been speculated that Daniel Ortega has undermined the electoral process and other branches of government. In doing so, he has managed to keep a hold on his position of power and rule with what many peg as an "iron fist". In wake of dialogues from the multiple protests spewing from over the years from human rights violations and economic struggle, President Ortega has agreed to release demonstration protesters who were arrested. As the government creates stricter limitations for opposition, talks have ensued about electoral reform. However, it is likely that President Ortega will remain in his position until after July 2019--potentially until the next election in 2021as he rejected efforts to move it up.  Sources:

This is less rigorous than the way I approach other questions, because I think this question involves more uncertainty than others, so there's a lower payoff to spending more time analysing information.     • Protests mostly over.
    • US has blocked most loans. Economy shrank 4% in 2018. This will take some serious hard work to overcome.
    • Ortega can fall if:
        ◦ New elections are called (a couple of percent at most, given that the next election is scheduled for 2021 and the Sandinistas have 71/92 seats in the legislature)
        ◦ Assassination (<1%)
        ◦ Coup (a couple of percent at most)
            ▪ To me this seems most likely if he really is in financial trouble. But the next 6 months is a small time frame.
        ◦ Foreign intervention
            ▪ 2-4% probability of US intervention given by the paper “Why Does the United States Intervene Abroad? Democracy, Human Rights Violations, and Terrorism” for countries of similar circumstances
            ▪ Might have to adjust down given that an intervention is <100% to be successful
        ◦ Natural death (he’s 73, and it’d be possible to calculate this more rigorously, but I suspect it’s 1-2% for the next six months)
    • So let’s call 2% for new elections, 0.5% for assassination, 3% for coups, 2% for foreign intervention, and 1.5% for natural death = 7%
    • Although I do think 3% for coups might be an overestimate.
I am trying to defer to base rates for this.  I could expect an outside shock, like a new recession, could dislodge him, but that is a more complex proposition.

For a while the uprising looked set to dethrone Ortega, 73, whose cold war tussle with Washington made him a revolutionary icon but who is now increasingly seen as an autocrat. But a counter-attack by security forces and armed paramilitary gangs in July helped Ortega reclaim control of the streets and force thousands of dissidents into exile. Since then, he has continued to turn up the heat on opponents, banning street protests and, most recently, targeting NGOs and media outlets who were documenting the turmoil. Journalists have been subjected to a campaign of intimidation and violence intended to snuff out coverage of the crisis, which activists blame for upwards of 325 deaths.

Political unrest in Nicaragua has caused the deaths of more than 300 anti-government protesters in the past year. Since July, President Ortega has repeatedly rejected calls for him to step down or to hold early elections. He has instead targeted the anti-government protesters, calling them terrorists. In the past few months, the government has increasingly cracked down on protesters. The movement appears to be dying down as a result of the government's aggressive actions. Furthermore, protesters do not have enough leverage against the President, who over the years has consolidated political power. His wife is the vice president, and they currently have control over the judiciary, parliament, armed forces, and police. All this suggests that it is unlikely that Ortega will cease to be President of Nicaragua by July 1st, 2019 https://www.reuters.com/article/us-nicaragua-protests/nicaraguan-police-arrest-protesters-quash-anti-government-march-idUSKCN1MO0S8

Daniel Ortega, Nicaragua's President, stands accused of unleashing a wave of violent reprisals by government forces against opposition groups. Press accounts list the death toll at over 300 protestors. The attention of the Organization of American States (OAS), of which the U.S. is a permanent member state, has shifted towards Ortega's Nicaragua as international accounts paint a dire picture of a despotic regime. Allegations of human rights violations have drawn the condemnation of the OAS Secretary General. The situation seems to be escalating. Amnesty International now believes it has evidence of extrajudicial killings. Ortega, who assumed power in the 70s after leading a revolution, refuses to transition power after four terms in office. Considering the U.S. history of intervention in Nicaragua in the form of the Contras during the 1980s, and the nations history of violence, there certainly is a quiet potential for internal or external action that could lead to ousting Ortega from office.

I think that there is the chance that Ortega's regime will be toppled before next July, but it's relatively unlikely as he has been clinging to power for some time that he would not simply step down or be dramatically forced out, as it likely would have already happened with the height of the protests earlier this year. The next elections are not due until 2020, so unless there is a threat of violence that would force Ortega out of office, he would likely not be taken out of power until 2020, and that is only if the elections are not rigged in his favor. So there are basically two likely outcomes for the transition of power: either Ortega is forcefully/violently removed from office, like Allende was in Chile through a violent military coup with outside (US) support, which is unlikely since the international community will likely not get involved militarily or through the use of violence; alternatively, if there is enough international pressure, it is possible that Ortega would leave office relatively voluntarily after the 2020 election, as Pinochet did in Chile at the end of the 1980s based on domestic and international concern and protests.

WASHINGTON—The Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN) issued an advisory today to alert U.S. financial institutions of the increasing risk that proceeds of political corruption from Nicaragua may enter or traverse the U.S. financial system. FinCEN expects that senior foreign political figures connected to the regime of Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega could react to the perceived threat of further unrest, potential sanctions, or other factors by moving assets out of their accounts in Nicaragua or elsewhere. These assets could be the proceeds of corruption, and they may be directed into U.S. accounts, or laundered through the U.S. financial system. FinCEN requests that financial institutions file Suspicious Activity Reports (SARs), consistent with their existing Bank Secrecy Act (BSA) obligations, when they identify potential misuse of Nicaraguan public funds or potential proceeds of political corruption associated with senior foreign political figures connected to the Ortega regime.
See the press release at https://www.fincen.gov/news/news-releases/fincen-advisory-warns-risks-linked-corruption-nicaragua

Based on the history of conflict due to President Ortega, it seems likely that this violence will escalate. President Ortega made changes to the constitution in 2006 in order to stay in office, and despite negative backlash from the public, he continues to fight for power. Since April of 2018, many protesters have died in uprisings calling for Ortega to leave office, and those protests have been met with military force. The protests are composed of people who are multi-ethnic, come from separate political factions as well as economic backgrounds, and the international community has condemned the actions of the government of Nicaragua. Despite condemnation and backlash from thousands of people from the country, Ortega continues to use military and political power to hold his seat. He used his immunity to prevent trial for allegations of child abuse from his step-daughter, and has also shown many other instances of high-level corruption. Because Ortega is willing to go to extremes to remain president and to have this position of power, it is unlikely that he will leave office within one year. Due to the unstable nature and violence insinuated by the protests, it is unlikely that the movement will make an effect until there is a uniting force, which is unlikely before July of 2019. It is unlikely because although businesses have began to feel the effects of the corruption from the presidency, they do not have that much of a voice in Nicaragua because it's one of the poorest countries in Nicaragua. The widespread poverty does not allow for a strong business influence in stopping Ortega, so although they are against Ortega, external influence needs to be implemented. Based off history of international institutions and intervention, in order for them to act, the crisis needs to be more widespread, or national interests of powerful states must be aligned with the politics of Nicaragua. Since the end of the Cold War, the U.S. has not had interests in Nicaragua because the military is no longer aimed at combating communists, but instead terrorists. Other powerful world actors have not indicated interests in Nicaragua either, so it is unlikely there will be an intervention besides sanctions before escalation, which is unlikely to happen until protests become more organized and widespread, which will not happen before July of 2019 due to the chaos in the organization of protests and violence happening currently. https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-44398673

The oil prices is at the highest it has been. Ortega will bury every poster here at the start of his century long rule.  Guerrillero Heroico - Che Guevara 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:CheHigh.jpg Venezuelan oil fueled the rise and fall of Nicaragua’s Ortega regime
“Oil diplomacy” was standard practice in Venezuela at the time. In the early 2000s, Venezuela was one of Latin America’s richest countries. Chávez used his economic brawn to support allies in Cuba, Argentina, Ecuador and Brazil by sending them financial aid and cheap crude. Venezuela offered the Ortega regime unusually favorable terms of trade. His government paid 50 percent of the cost of each shipment within 90 days of receipt. The remainder was due within 23 years and financed at 2 percent interest. This cheap fuel was distributed at market prices by Nicaragua’s government gas company, DNP. The government’s nice profit margin helped spur a period of remarkable economic growth in Nicaragua. Between 2007 and 2016, Ortega’s government spent nearly 40 percent of oil proceeds to bolster ambitious social welfare programs, including micro-financing for small businesses, food for the hungry and subsidized housing for the poor. These initiatives contributed to significant poverty reductions across Nicaragua, earning Ortega and his Sandinista party widespread popular support. Between 2007 and 2017, Nicaragua’s gross domestic product grew at an average of 4.1 percent a year. The boom peaked in 2012, with a stunning 6.4 percent growth in GDP. The year before, Venezuela had sent a record $557 million in oil to Nicaragua – the equivalent of 6 percent of the Central American country’s total gross domestic product.

“There is no persecution in Nicaragua,” Ortega told Carolina Chimoy in an exclusive interview, in Managua, with Germany’s Deutsche Welle (DW). “Who are the coup-plotters? They are troops who are being supplied by the United States,” he said. “The best support that Germany can give us is to tell the United States that they shouldn’t meddle in Nicaragua,” Ortega added. The Nicaraguan president also said that despite the crisis, and the demands by the protesters, Civic Alliance and the clerty, among others calling for his stepping down and calling early elections in March 2019, he will not. The next presidential elections Elections are slated to take place in 2021. http://todaynicaragua.com/daniel-ortega-blames-nicaragua-crisis-on-us-backed-coup-in-interview-with-dw/ EFE: Who is responsible for what has happened these months in the streets of Nicaragua, with all the dead there? Ortega: We have a long and well-known history that we always have to take into account: this is a power called the United States of America. It has been intervening and occupying Nicaragua since the 1850s and there has been Yankee expansionism here. What brought them here? The Gold Rush. Nicaragua was a much more comfortable and a safer route instead of traveling across the North American territory from the east coast to the west coast. Transport companies found in us a more comfortable and safer route. Once opened up, then came American expansionism and a fixation with opening a canal. EFE: And now you maintain that the United States is behind the incidents? Ortega: It’s the same old story. We left government after the 1990 elections, we acknowledged the results of those elections and the right-wing there began a policy of seeking to restore all the economic, political and cultural power that the U.S. had previously imposed and which we had already ended when we deposed the Somoza dictatorship. It was during that period that they were able to reimpose
